dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1 A glimpse of sunlight desperately tries to force its way through a gray sky before being obliterated. 4 A MAN, sunburned and bearded, lets himself fall from the of a boat and into the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNDERWATER, through shafts of light, white limbs are FLAILING. The MAN struggles, alone. Bubbles stream upward He breaks the surface and gasps for air. He begins to swim. His massive arms and shoulders grab at tide in large, hard strokes. His legs and feet are buried beneath the dark ocean water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 A floating tenement. A crane LOWERS a fishing net into the water. The MAN swim into it. The net is RAISED as he lays, motionless, within grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 The crane swings around with the MAN in the net. He is EMPTIED out onto the deck like a fish. AHIVERING on the rotting wooden planks he FLIPS himself o on his stomach. Slowly, using the palms of his hands, he DRAGS his trunk and withered limbs across the deck in a labored lobster-walk. He uses his chest muscles to swing his legs around the ed of the boat. They dangle like pieces of rope, his feet wh and flaccid. A towel, a bottle and a glass are wordlessly placed next him by a CREW PERSON. He pours himself a generous amount scotch and begins drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same MAN is illuminated by the light of a single cand He is dancing, holding on tightly to a WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though the light is dim it is clear that he is clean shav with his hair neatly trimmed. Their connection is powerful and alive. They stop dancing overwhelmed with mutual desire. He holds the WOMAN's face in his hands and KISSES it all over, moving into a realm of feeling that is foreign to h He kisses her passionately on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear... His fingers run softly over the outside of her breasts. S begins to undo the back of her dress and slips it down ar her ankles. Wearing only her tight corset she brings his hands to the laces and together they undo it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, darling. It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 OSCAR, a manservant, is carrying both a silver tray and a pair of pants over his extended arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar! Where the devil are you? Deftly, Oscar opens the door to a spacious bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My apologies, Mr. Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 There with his bare legs, muscular and lean, sporting bla socks held up with garters is FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT, He projects a natural elegance and the confidence of a ma who can have anything he wants. Right now... he wants his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been standing here for five minutes. Oscar offers the tray to Franklin which bear cuff links a Tiffany watch which Franklin grabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you sleep well, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't remember. That's good, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Franklin takes his pants from Oscar and steps into them, pulling the suspenders up and over his shoulders. 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striding into the dining room, Franklin lifts a silver li off a breakfast plate. He dismisses it and instead pours himself a cup of coffee from a silver pot on the sideboar He overhears a voice from the nearby sitting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could not be more delighted to have received your most charming letter. It has been far too long since we last corresponded. However, it is with great reluctance I must decline your kind speaking invitation... 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEANOR ROOSEVELT, 34, is dictating a letter. Her enormou eyes, liquid and blue, reveal a woman of extraordinary intelligence and depth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, I would be of little assistance to the Junior Assistance League. Particularly if my purpose were to appear as an alumna who is gifted at public speaking. She is dictating to LUCY MERCER, 27, deeply feminine with head of soft dark hair and an accommodating nature. She i Eleanor's social secretary and closest friend. She is also the WOMAN dancing with Franklin the night bef

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you really want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you and if you ask again I shall scream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a laugh -- which is not shared by the homely rumpled mess of a man draped over a sofa in the corner. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask your husband for some pointers? He's a pretty gifted public speaker, don't you think? LOUIS HOWE, 48, is a wizened man of limited stature and unlimited soul. Franklin's political advisor extraordinai part consiglieri and part priest. He is the mastermind be what he believes will be the greatest political career of twentieth century. He gets up and leans in closely to Eleanor. A cigarette d off his lip and the smoke rises up and curls in her face. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should get out once in a while. Accepting that invitation would be good for Franklin's career. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Howe, wouldn't you be more comfortable waiting for my husband outside? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the street, Mrs. Roosevelt? ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like. Eleanor smiles oh-so politely at Louis, as Franklin enter from the dining room. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see it's not even eight a.m. and already the gloves are off. (kissing Eleanor on the cheek) Good morning, Babs. Hello, Miss Mercer.   L UCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir. Quickly, she lowers her eyes to her work. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) You're late. Honestly, why do you enjoy keeping people waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they always seem more grateful to see me when I arrive. He leans in and kisses Eleanor on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a lovely day, Babs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I expect you for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the Navy reception this evening. I'll be home quite late. Unless you've changed your mind about coming? Louis looks up from his paper at Lucy who is writing furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you wish me to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... whatever you'd like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well then. (tipping his hat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Miss Mercer. Lucy nods and Franklin exits. Then Louis tips his hat to ladies and follows him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 A car pulls over and Franklin is first out, followed by Louis, walking at a brisk pace as they cross the opposite side of the street. Louis struggles to keep up while consulting a small appointment book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ten you've got a meeting with representatives from Pittsburgh Steel. Their bid on the ship building contract has already been turned in and is on your desk for approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I think of it? An AFRICAN-AMERICAN man steps off the curb, letting Frank and Louis pass. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had some problems with it. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better read it. Steel workers tend to vote democratic. Next. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch with Secretary Daniels. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must I? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your boss. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) What if she'd said yes? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Louis shoots him a look that says "you know who." LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People know. It's time to stop. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can handle my own affairs, Louis. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this one. This is Washington, D.C., not the Harvard Club. (off-put by Franklin's arrogance) How can you be so cavalier? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say that like it's a bad thing. Louis takes a quick last drag on his cigarette and follow him inside a building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 A large grandfather clock reads 3:00. The sound of a key in the front door turns and Franklin quietly enters. His hair is a mess and his clothing is slightly askew. As he comes through the hall two eyes shine in the darkne They belong to Eleanor sitting rigidly on a settee, liste to the sound of Franklin's footsteps going up the stairs. 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin goes into his bedroom. Eleanor quietly comes up stairs and stops for a brief moment by Franklin's door, t goes off to her bedroom closing the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 Franklin lays sleeping in his bed as Eleanor enters quiet so as not to wake him. Carefully she picks up a set of keys on the dresser then turns and notices a packet of letters sitting on top of a open duffle bag. Tentatively she reaches for them. She brings the packet, with a piece of ribbon, up to her nose. She is shocked by their familiar scent. With trembling hands she unties the ribbon. Tears flood d her cheeks as she reads. Franklin opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Springwood is the three-story Roosevelt mansion. It is surrounded by a thousand acres of forests, fields, bridal paths and a glorious view of the Hudson River. THE FIVE ROOSEVELT CHILDREN are screaming on the front la playing a boisterous game of croquet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 SARA ROOSEVELT, 65, sits at the head of the table. She is for whom the expression "Grande Dame" was coined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin is at the opposite end of the table, looking pal Louis, as always, is by his side. Eleanor, like a prisoner who has accepted her fate, sits across from them, calm and composed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have offered Franklin his freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I have accepted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eleanor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His freedom is not yours to offer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am in love with Miss Mercer, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord save us from fools in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falling in love is out of the question. Why do you think men have mistresses? Duty. Duty to their families and their careers. Eleanor rises from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's obvious that my input in this matter is of little importance. She begins to exit the room, but Franklin is up like a sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back here! Both of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 Franklin chases Eleanor. Midway up the stairs, she turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know whether to hate you or thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For forcing me to face my life honestly for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to hurt you, Babs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never do. You live your life skimming the surface... never aware of the attachments beneath. (finding her anger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be a luxury. She goes up the stairs without looking back. 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin slowly walks back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divorce will finish your career in politics. How do you intend to support yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My trust fund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divorce Eleanor and there is no trust fund. Franklin turns away. He looks out the large picture windo and attempts to light a cigarette, but his hands shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've come so far, boss. State Assembly, Assistant Secretary of the Navy -- all pages right out of Cousin Teddy's play book. We're on the road to the White House. Don't do this. Franklin sees his son, ELLIOT, 10, playing separately fro the rest of his siblings. Elliot looks up at his father a Franklin bares his best politician's smile at him. A ROAR begins to fill his ears. It becomes clearer that i the sound of a CROWD CHEERING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose-velt! Rose-velt! Rose-velt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 CONVENTIONEERS shout out Franklin's name holding up PLACA emblazoned with:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin BOLTS, running vigorously down the center aisle the hall lit by the circle of a spotlight. The CROWD goes wild over this unconventional entrance.

dialogues.speaker: W
dialogues.text: hen he reaches the edge of the stage he LEAPS onto it. Th final act of daring pushes the crowd into frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 Smiling for no one. For everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I humbly accept your nomination for Vice-President! The CROWD roars back in reaction to his less-than-humble

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say the best way to get   rid of a man is to have him run for   Vice- President. (he holds for the laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might well have asked my   cousin Teddy if that's how they got   rid of him! Franklin stands on the stage, the music rising, the crowd cheering. Slowly, the sound of the convention fades to something far more delicate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 A harp playing in an elegant tea room. The hushed tones o polite conversation wafts through the air. Franklin sits with his cousin, ALICE ROOSEVELT, 36, daugh of Teddy. Brilliant and acerbic, she would have had a car in politics had she been born a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you lost. A Roosevelt on the democratic ticket? Our ancestors are turning in their graves. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Alice, if Teddy were alive he'd be a democrat -- and you know it. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rubbish. But I do know one thing: You're exactly like him. My father was born wanting only one thing: to be President. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's wrong with that? They both share a laugh. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what they're saying about you? Franklin's smile fades. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I'm sure you'll tell me. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say F.D.R. stands for "featherduster." That you're a lightweight. A dilettante with no substance; no point of view. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you think? ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lead with your vanity. You talk when you should listen. Unless these are the qualities of a democrat? F RANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The democratic party is the party of the people. I am a man of the people. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, you're a Roosevelt. What do you know about people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans in conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I can think of one person you did manage to find the time to invest in. A Miss Mercer, I believe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice, stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't misunderstand me, Franklin. Being married to Eleanor I think you deserved some fun. But you made the right decision. Especially since Miss Mercer has gone on with her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward Rutherford is a wonderful catch for a girl like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last week. A small event, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I last heard she was governess to his children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then love bloomed. As a "man of the people," I wouldn't be too hard on her, Franklin. We can't all have trust funds you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 Franklin, Louis and a PHOTOGRAPHER disembark from a touri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not taking this defeat lying down, boss. We'll run you for Governor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding) Really? Of which state? Louis shoots him a look. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny. No, this buys you time. It buys you experience. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Al Smith? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's vulnerable. You're still a fresh face, boss. We'll use that to our advantage. They walk down a hill towards some waiting Boy Scouts as PHOTOGRAPHER follows them. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy Scouts, Louis? Hardly my political base. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got parents. Besides they're photogenic. Franklin begins glad-handing the assembled group of mostl underprivileged children. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin Roosevelt, happy to meet you. Franklin masks his thinly veiled discomfort with an artificial good cheer. Meanwhile, Louis, in full politica mode, makes sure the L Photographer gets everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here! Franklin poses with two Scouts. The picture is taken. SCOUTMASTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boys, lunch. Line up to wash! (to Franklin) Will you be joining us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin steps into a line before a large communal water barrel and glances sideways at GUISEPPE, 9, an immigrant child of the city streets. He wears his uniform proudly a smiles at Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guiseppe. Franklin puts his arm around Guiseppe, forcing the moment between them. He waits patiently as the cameras click awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guiseppe! Come sta, ragazzo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I guess. The SCOUTS begin washing their hands together in the wate barrel and Franklin joins in as Louis looks on admiringly As Guiseppe splashes some of the water on his face, Frank not to be outdone, does so as well. It's all for the came

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 A large but unpretentious house with a sweeping lawn that looks out over the icy waters of the Bay of Fundy. 22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor sits quietly on the front porch knitting -- in a world of her own. A few feet away -- also in a world of his own -- sits Lou overdressed for summer in a three piece suit. An overflow ashtray is by his side and piles of newspaper lie at his feet. He holds up a paper to Eleanor with the photo of Franklin the Boy Scouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a natural. Eleanor gives it a cursory glance then looks out to where Franklin and the children come bounding up the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin and Elliot break out from the rest and begin rac up the lawn. Franklin, no match for his son's speed, lose He doubles over, trying to catch his breath. ELLIOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vae victis! ("Woe to the conquered!")

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: aught up in his victory, Elliot doesn't see Franklin snea up behind him and tackle him to the ground. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Festina lente! ("Not so fast!") One by one the other children all pile on top of Franklin Elliot. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner is in one half-hour! Come in and change, children! FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up! Up, chicks! You heard your mother! Everyone runs up the porch stairs and into the house exce Franklin. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go wash up. Utterly spent, Franklin lays on the grass, not moving. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, boss! Are you all right? Slowly, Franklin gets up and walks with great effort up t porch stairs. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. (re: her knitting) Oh, that's pretty, Babs. He puts his hand on Eleanor's shoulder and leans in to bu her cheek but Eleanor quickly stands. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must check on dinner. There is a cursory formality to her words and little warm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. She goes into the house. Louis then hands Franklin letter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of you? Never. Wearily, he sorts through the envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you nap before dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, dear. Franklin heads into the house leaning heavily against the screen door struggling for control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 Franklin lays on a chaise being examined by a DOCTOR, who leans over him holding out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you take my hand? Franklin tries, but can't. Almost his entire body is paralyzed. He can only breathe and blink. The Doctor glances at Eleanor, Louis and Sara indicating should follow him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 As the door from the sun room opens onto the porch, Ellio there waiting. Seeing them coming, he dashes off into the yard so as not to be seen as Eleanor, Louis, Sara and the Doctor enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has Infantile Paralysis. Polio. Sara sinks into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. I knew it. D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: thought it only struck children. OCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessarily. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he get it? DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some experts believe it is linked to contaminated water. But that theory is speculative at best. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the visit to that god damned Boy Scout Camp! DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In all honesty you need to be looking forward, not back. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the prognosis? DR. LOVETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The damage to his leg muscles is extensive. I suspect he will be paralyzed from the waist down. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God. beat) And the children? DR. LOVETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they don't have any symptoms by now then they have been spared. Sara stands -- her bearing once again erect and proud. SARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we must count our blessings. R. LOVETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will need to prepare yourselves. There is a deep depression that follows an illness of this magnitude. I'm afraid life as he knew it is over. Their discussion is suddenly interrupted by the sound of child crying. Eleanor rushes off the porch to the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 Eleanor finds Elliot, having heard everything, curled up ball, weeping. She leans down and wraps her arms around h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pink background covered in small white flowers with red centers and green leaves. There is a seam in the paper. A tiny white spot where glue has soaked through. PULL BACK TO REVEAL - Franklin in bed. This is all he stares at -- hour after hour after hour. His lips are dry. A glass of water sits tantalizingly on the night stand. H reaches for it but it's a few inches out of his reach. Slowly, he begins to rock his torso back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 Sara, Eleanor and Louis are in heated conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that politics are out of the question he can stay here at home with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what kind of life is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've rented him an office downtown. He can still practice law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you want to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he needs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can pursue a career, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man as proud and vital as Franklin... you're inviting him to be hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, Mr. RA(cont'd) SA Howe, engaged in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fantasy of a political future for my son... is there nothing you won't do to keep your job? Sara leaves as Eleanor goes after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama! That's not fair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 Franklin, still rocking his torso, has now gained some momentum, managing to have moved just a few inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 Sara busies herself arranging flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of life is it to be pitied and stared at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of life is it to be hidden away? I know you believe that what you are suggesting for Franklin is best. But I think you are making it harder for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know what's best for Franklin. I am his mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I am his wife. Sara stares at Eleanor in disbelief. Eleanor stares back unflinching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 Franklin reaches his arm towards the glass only to fall f the bed to the floor with a thud. Frustrated beyond words Franklin lunges at his wheelchair and shoves it across th floor letting out an anguished cry. In agony, from both the pain and the humiliation, he star up and fixes his gaze on the ornate ceiling overhead. Then, closing his eyes, a POUNDING in his head starts to louder and louder --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 Franklin, on his back, his face and body drenched with sw is asleep in his bunk in the boat. He awakens to the soun the POUNDING. Voices are calling him accompanied by FISTS smashing at the door. He opens his eyes and is disoriente He tries to sit up -- momentarily forgetting that he can'

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: e lifts the sheet and visibly WINCES in disgust at the si of his crippled legs. BONES covered by FLESH with barely ounce of muscle. Finally the door BURSTS open.   Two young crewman, EUGENE STANLEY enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roosevelt, we got a storm comin'! He lifts Franklin over his shoulder. Stanley grabs clothe pulls a set of long iron leg braces from a hook off the w Eugene grabs a bucket and holds Franklin up to urinate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (while peeing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me here. Let the ocean swallow me up. Burial at sea. Perfect for a navy man. Stripped to his underwear Franklin is laid across the bun Eugene kneels and puts on Franklin's socks and shoes. The and Stanley slide on his braces and pants. Their hands zipper, clasp, buckle and tie. Each hand work synchronicity with the other. Clumsily they lift Franklin up, struggling under his weig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 Eugene and Stanley carry Franklin off in the driving rain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 Kerosene lamps light the diner which is filled with peopl mostly fishermen, seeking refuge from the coming storm. Franklin, soaked-to-the-skin and wrapped in a blanket, is being pushed through the door by Eugene in a wheelchair. The restaurant collectively pauses to take them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin is slowly wheeled across the restaurant. He shri from the stares of the patrons. A LITTLE GIRL eating with her parents gets excited when s sees Franklin's braces and points. Franklin gives her a h look and she is hurt. What he can't see is that under the table she wears a set braces like his. Franklin is wheeled up to his table and EUGENE and STANLE down with him. Louis enters resembling a drowned rat. He rips off his ha and raincoat and puts down his suitcase. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely surprised) Louis? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never miss Florida in the rainy season. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No letter? No wire? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Would you have answered it? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you too. Nice whiskers. You look like Chester Arthur. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley, this is Mr. Howe. He gets sea-sick at the mere sight of a boat so he's probably happy that it's being Ldestroyed right now. OUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, I need to talk to Mr. Roosevelt alone. Find your own breakfast. Here's a five spot. Make it a feast. They look at the money and take their leave. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're always so generous with my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean your mother's, don't you? The Waitress puts down two cups of coffee. Franklin pulls a flask and pours some into his cup. He then lights a cigarette and begins smoking, but doesn't offer one to Lo Without asking, Louis helps himself. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Mama financed this fool's errand, has she? Well, it's a waste of a trip. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Eleanor's idea. Franklin's face is immobile. WAITRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I get you? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like some ham and eggs, sunny side up, please? (to Franklin) What's your fancy, boss? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I fancy nothing. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll have the same. The Waitress grabs their menus and scurries away. Louis o his briefcase and hands Franklin a stack of mail. Frankli glances it, but doesn't open any. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a few from your children. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can still read. Franklin flips through the mail and finds a letter that interests him, opening it. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife wants you to come home. (choosing his words) She's concerned. I'm concerned. This life on a boat... where is it getting you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting me? For one thing, no one gets to see me and I don't get to see them. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that. Everyone's waiting for you to come home. The kids... they're aching to see you. RANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Really? Louis looks sadly at his friend. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: skimming the letter) From George Foster Peabody. He owns a resort in rural Georgia for investment purposes. Hot springs or something. He claims that only recently a crippled boy swam in the waters and can walk again. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for Chrissake... FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

The high magnesium content of these natural springs will hold anyone up. Although it is not a resort for infirm types I am extending you my personal invitation to come visit in the off- season." (putting the letter aside) I'm only welcome in the "off- season." Eugene and Stanley approach the table. EUGENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roosevelt, we got bad news. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: F

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the boat... it got banged up real bad tied to the dock. RANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad? STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you can stay there anymore. ranklin absorbs this. EUGENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's a blessing in disguise, Mr. Roosevelt. I don't know about you, but I'm homesick. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm sick of home. (to Louis) Where's the letter from Peabody? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be serious? He hands Franklin the letter who rereads it. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not miracle waters? I've drunk the oil of monkey glands, been zapped with electricity and hung upside down in harnesses. After all that, this sounds downright peaceful. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't quite picture you in the back woods of Georgia. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you picture me, Louis? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President, Louis? I can't visit the bathroom without a team of associates to help pull my pants down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it a little time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a reason they say a man runs for office. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Georgia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 Franklin and Eleanor sit next to one another. Franklin is shaved and cleaned up considerably. However, the tension between them is palpable. Eleanor kn furiously while talking. Franklin looks out the window at African-American FIELD HANDS hard at work in the red clay hills of Georgia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James has been doing so much better now that Elliot has joined him at Groton. They've put their differences behind them and have become a real team. Franklin observes two YOUNG BOYS, African-American, runni alongside the slow-moving train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two peas in a pod. Last week they were both in the infirmary with the F         same cold. ranklin eyes a wagon pulled by a mule. The driver, a FARM takes off his hat and wipes his brow in the hot sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, any suggestion I make to Anna for her future -- she dismisses me. I am going to have to enlist your support in this, Franklin. She listens to you. She looks over at Franklin and sees that he is staring ou window, deep in thought -- not having heard a word she's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 TOM LOYLESS, 39, stands waiting by a car dressed in a whi suit. Laconic, with a dry sense of humor, Tom is a man of words whose poker face hides a true desperation. He holds telegram from Franklin in his hand. As the train pulls in Tom looks for Franklin among the passengers making their exit. There are two different exits on the platform clearly mar WHITE and COLORED. Whites exit from the front of the trai and Blacks from the rear. LIONEL PURDY, tiny, and dressed in a mailman's uniform, approaches Tom. Of indeterminate age and dubious intellec his mail bag is almost as big as he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might say so, Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mr. Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. The STATIONMASTER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, your guest needs some assistance. We're gonna need some able-bodied men to move him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lionel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go over to the livery stable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and get the Collier boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 Franklin exits the train slung in a fireman's carry over shoulder of ROY COLLIER, African-American, 29. His brothe PETE, 27, is close behind, carrying luggage -- both hover around 6' 4". Tom approaches. Franklin attempts to hide his embarrassme with good cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello! Hello! Mr. Loyless?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, Mr. Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'd better call me Franklin. Still in the fireman's carry, Franklin extends his hand f Tom to shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is the Misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to make your acquaintance. Roy then carries him over to Tom's car and gingerly place him inside. Pete follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a trunk and a chair with the wheels, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send a wagon right over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a wagon, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 Tom drives Franklin in front, Eleanor sits in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pine trees tower over the sides of the dirt road. In occasional clearings, Franklin spies barefoot children playing out in front of broken-down shacks. They stop the play to look at the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering his discomfort)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been manager of the Inn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long. They BANG over a large pothole. They all fly up and land

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any paved roads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Tom's car turns into a driveway. Franklin has a brochure "The Meriwether Inn" opened in his lap. He tries to spy t building through the trees but cannot. He looks back at the brochure. The picture is of a lavish Victorian Hotel and the words, "Our renowned mineral hot springs can cure whatever ails you!" Franklin looks up and sees a three-story hideous green an yellow monstrosity leaning slightly to one side. Paint is peeling everywhere. What once were flower beds are overgr with weeds. The car pulls to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have a great deal of privacy. There are only a few guests right now as it's the off- season... I'm hoping to make some improvements by next Spring -- Franklin puts out his arm preventing Tom from getting out the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I can't stay here. This place is a wreck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look on the bright side. Most of your time will be spent in the water. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true, we've fallen on some hard times...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard times? This is a disaster! It should be condemned! Tom's southern manners are being put to the test, but he stays remarkably calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we've seen better days. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then I imagine so have you. Franklin blinks incomprehensibly at Tom and what he has j said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy to drive you back to the train station right now, if that's what you want. They lock eyes. Franklin wonders if Tom's bluffing, but h can't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire. I'm frightened of fire. I can't get out if I'm upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 Tom's car is now parked in front of a group of small cottages. Roy and Pete's horse drawn wagon is behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 Tom and Pete open a set of shutters over the windows of a tiny cottage. Franklin and Eleanor sit in the car, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 Sheets cover the furniture, cobwebs span the beams and du particles fill the air. As Tom maneuvers the wheelchair through the front door, Franklin notices a broken window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caustic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ventilated, at least. Roy enters with a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you want this, Mr. Roosevelt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom, Roy, thank you. He looks after Roy as he exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, this young man appears quite competent. Would you ask him if he'd like to stay on as my valet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask him yourself? He tips his hat and goes outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Pete, alone, drives the wagon past the Inn and out onto t road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 Eleanor stands in the middle of the tiny living room stun by the squalor. She speaks to Franklin who is changing in other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is madness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me again, Franklin, why are we here? Franklin is wheeled out by Roy, now changed into a bathin suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the waters. Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 Roy wheels Franklin while Tom walks in front of them lead the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Roosevelt want to swim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Roosevelt doesn't know how. Franklin takes in the surroundings. Deserted horse stable total ruin and tennis courts covered with underbrush mar landscape. 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An immense, T-shaped pool rimmed in concrete. The bluish water is clear and sparkling and a delicate steam rises o of the warmth.

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: MOTHER, eyeing Franklin approaching in his wheelchair, comes to the edge of the pool and coaxes her CHILDREN out the water. AUNT SALLY, an ancient, gaunt, African American woman, st guard by the edge of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roosevelt, I'd like you to meet Aunt Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, sir. I have towels for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy wheels Franklin as close to the rim of the pool as possible. Tom lends his assistance and both he and Roy HO Franklin out of the chair and place him at the edge, lett his feet dangle in the warm water. Twisting on his massive arms, Franklin lowers himself cau

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now give it a minute. You'll see that the mineralization makes the water more buoyant. The crippled boy who swam here was actually able to walk in the water. Franklin's legs flop as his useless feet touch the shallo bottom. Crushed, all hope drains from his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't even stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 Roy sleeps on a couch on the front porch. Crickets hum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 Eleanor tosses and turns on a roll away bed. 48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin lies in bed staring up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 A handful of guests are spread out in a huge dining room. Franklin and Eleanor sit together. He is eating heartily, Eleanor merely moves her food around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is simply revolting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not very good, but it is mysterious. (holding out his plate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the world do you think they've poured over this chicken? Or is it possum? Eleanor sizes Franklin up. She knows this is a preamble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York has the best doctors and hospitals in the country. F RANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need something new. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't about getting better is it? You don't want to come home. You don't want to live with us. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I refuse to be a burden to anyone. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a burden, you're my husband. e reaches out and takes her hand in his. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to offer you the freedom you once so generously offered me. (she pulls it away) All you've ever known is duty. To me and to a political career that unless I can walk no longer exists. You've been exemplary. Now I'm telling you you're free to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her voice rising) No. (a beat) I don't want freedom. I want a marriage. I want a life with you. Franklin won't let himself believe it. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't imagine what you think that life is going to be. This takes the wind out of Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Franklin... it's not up to me to imagine, it's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor folds her napkin and gets up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 Pete helps Eleanor into his livery wagon. Franklin watches from the porch as Eleanor rides away. He suitcase slides across the open wagon bed, as the wagon m the tight turn from the driveway onto the main road.

dialogues.speaker: ON ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Looking out -- straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: ON FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Alone and scared as he watches the wagon fade from sight. 51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor is pouring tea for Louis, who is seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for stopping by, Mr. Howe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might want to see a friendly face. (off the silence) So how's our boy doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's enjoying the waters very much. He... (suddenly overwhelmed) I think we've lost him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her pent-up tears burst in a free-flow. Louis leads her t nearby settee and hands her his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please excuse me, Mr. Howe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's time you called me Louis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we've been going about this all wrong. He's down there to be alone so let's give him what he wants. We change our focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what? Louis smiles, knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 The row of abandoned cottages look strangely pretty, aglo the setting sun. 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin is seated on the ramshackle porch in his chair. cigarette hangs from his lip as he mixes martinis in a gl milk bottle. He pours one for Tom, then himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To your mineral pool, or whatever you call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm Springs. They clink their glasses. Tom takes a polite sip, then ch back the bad taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too strong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't been in a drinking mood lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, its the most god-awful martini I've ever tasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you always this direct, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I never tasted a martini this bad before. Franklin takes another sip, checking. It tastes fine to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone likes my martinis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 Franklin's bed is already empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 Aunt Sally is seated, talking with Roy while Franklin lie his back in the water, swimming. All his movement comes f his shoulders and arms. The morning sun streams down on h Tom sits off to one side reading the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me more about what that boy did, Aunt Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, first he'd always swim over to the side of the pool and hold himself there -- make sure he righted himself. Then... before he knew it... he'd be standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it was only that easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you make it hard. Get over to the side of that pool and grab it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ( humoring her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you got to remember how you did it. Franklin holds the edge of the pool, closing his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a long moment there is silence. Almost without realiz it, Franklin lets go of the edge of the pool. When he opens his eyes -- he is standing -- all by himsel the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a nervous laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm standing. His laughter gets stronger. Tom, Aunt Sally and Roy look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm standing. The release is powerful as Franklin dissolves into tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 Tom, who's been mixing cocktails, hands Franklin a drink lifts his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To standing on your own two feet! They clink and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This water could be the cure -- the cure! In six months I could be up and walking! Lionel, the mailman, comes down the path carrying a flashlight, reading an open letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cocktail, Lionel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I'm working for the federal government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the more reason. (shoving a drink at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of late for the mail, isn't it? F L

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me it isn't. Got a whole packet of clippings for you, Mr. Roosevelt. From a Mr. Howe. New York Times, Journal-American... don't know what else. He hands an already opened letter to Franklin. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother wants to know when you're coming home. She says they got swimming pools in Hyde Park. She's mad as all hell. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reading other people's mail is not only impolite, it's illegal. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff don't mind. He likes I read his mail. Saves him the time. Plus a lot of folks around here can't read, so it's more a public service, really. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Astonishing. Thank you, Lionel. He hands Lionel a letter. IONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Miss Missy LeHand." Who's she? F RANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you must know, she's my social secretary. (to Tom) I'm having her come down. Lionel reaches into his bag. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost forgot... your wife wrote the nicest letter. She's gonna make a speech at the League of Women Voters. RANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me that. (

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the letter to Franklin who immediately begins reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says she's gonna keep the Roosevelt name alive. Least till he starts walkin' and all. Lionel takes the letter Franklin just handed him, opens i flicks his flashlight back on and continues on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying the letter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so unlike Eleanor. She's terrified of crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis and Eleanor approach a set of double doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are facing imminent disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take full responsibility if you hyperventilate or faint. They enter the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 At a lectern, behind which a banner reads "LEAGUE OF WOME VOTERS," the CHAIRWOMAN sees them and waves them forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, here she is now. Ladies, Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt. A small crowd of about two dozen women offer up polite, b scant applause for Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. I am so pleased to be invited here today. looking down at her cards)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too often.... A PHOTOGRAPHER snaps a picture which throws Eleanor off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too often... She stops. The pause is deadly. Louis looks ready to jump a window. Eleanor continues, her voice still pitched too ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too often the great decisions are originated and given form in bodies made up wholly of men... Slowly, she begins to find her voice. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that whatever political value women have to offer is shunted aside... without expression.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: his is a mistake. She looks up from her cards and stares at the audience... and for the first time speaks spontaneously. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this might be the reason I am having such a difficult time giving voice to my own thoughts here today. The immediacy of her self-effacing comment charms the roo ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm reminded of what someone once said about looking at an elephant. That it is impossible to ever see an entire elephant from one place -- you must walk around it. If our elected leaders are to be truly effective then they must be willing to go out of their way to look beyond what is right in front of them. To see the entire elephant. And for that... they need our help. The ladies applaud her, much to her relief. Louis beams.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: At a reception following the speech, Eleanor and the Chairwoman are drinking tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was so moving, Mrs. Roosevelt. The Child Welfare Amendment could use someone with your passion. You must consider being our spokesperson. Eleanor looks to Louis who nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. It would be an honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful. 59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin is attempting to walk in the water, working diligently. Tom watches him from a few paces back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I walked five steps today!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Listen, Franklin, I got word a local reporter wants to do a story on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hardly newsworthy these days. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he find out I'm here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small town -- word gets out. It probably won't amount to more than a provincial puff piece but it might give us some free publicity for the Inn. Franklin looks at Tom knowing full well he's arranged thi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I know the gentleman. I'm doing him a favor. You know, I used to be a journalist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean all this time I've been talking to a newspaper man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore. I got in a bit of trouble in Atlanta. Seems some of the editorial pieces I wrote offended the sensibilities of a local civic group. So I needed to lay low for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the Klan? Good God, Tom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thankfully, Mr. George Foster Peabody gave me this job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that explains a few things. For the life of me, I couldn't figure out why someone like you was running this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat-trap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing, swimming off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to say dump, but rat- trap fits nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 Franklin is seated -- but not in his wheelchair. He wears long pants even though it's blisteringly hot. CLEBURNE GREGORY, 28, sits across from Franklin -- a seco string reporter in a three-piece suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in 1920 when you were running for Vice-President...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't imagine your readers are interested in ancient history. Cox and I lost the election by a wide margin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was only a few years ago, Mr. Roosevelt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's the waters extra minerals plus its warmth that makes all the difference. At 90 degrees I can work my muscles for hours and not get cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Assistant Secretary of the Navy during the Great War did you condone the use of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot one more thing you will need to write down. Poor circulation is a chronic problem for people in my condition. Gregory looks at Franklin. It's clear he's not going to g the interview he came for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... you think it could be a cure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're hopeful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 Franklin is laid out on the bed as Roy slides the braces his legs. Roy unlaces his shoes and slips them off his fe e is about to put them under the bed when Franklin motion for Roy to hand them to him. Still flat on his back, Franklin luxuriates in the rich leather cobbled by hand. He examines their smooth, immacu soles... worn but never walked in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 A newspaper clipping of Eleanor in her speech to the Leag is taped to the wall. We hear the sound of an Underwood typewriter clacking awa and Franklin's voice, dictating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore, a formal questionnaire should be composed in order so we may hear from all recent delegates as to how we can do better in '28 to present a more united front. Signed, Franklin Roosevelt, etc., etc. MISSY LE HAND, 30, is sitting at a card table, typing. Brunette with some early gray, she is sturdy in build wit plain but friendly face. MISSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. Do you want this out today?    F RANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow will be fine. MISSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Missy, and c.c. that to Louis. Missy rises with a stack of envelopes and heads out. Roy enters with a plate of pancakes in front of Franklin. ROY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry, Mr. Roosevelt? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. ROY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you write to every morning? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different people I knew in politics. Just in case they ever want me back. ROY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll be ready when you get your legs workin' again? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the screen door. An earnest young man BENJAMIN PRENDERGAST, 18, is peering in. He has a newspap PRENDERGAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, are you Mr. Roosevelt? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Who are you? Roy opens the door to Prendergast, who enters. PRENDERGAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Benjamin Prendergast. I've come to see if you could speak at this year's graduation ceremony at the schoolhouse. You being so famous and all. Prendergast unfolds the newspaper. There is a picture of Franklin under the heading "FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT SWIMS HIS

dialogues.speaker: TO HEALTH
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be damned. PRENDERGAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you be available? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) When? Next spring? PRENDERGAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week. We only have a four month school year. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that possible? PRENDERGAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tax dollars only cover that much. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you graduating? PRENDERGAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. I'm the principal. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. But Franklin doesn't see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 A small breeze or a decent rain would knock it to the gro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 A bookshelf with four books. A few FARMERS and their WIVES sit with large groups of fi children. They look at Franklin askance. Prendergast stands proudly beside three GRADUATES-TO-BE. Tom stands in the back observing. Franklin, in his wheelchair, sits uncomfortably before th gathering. He notices a FATHER staring at his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that we're all here let me introduce to you to our guest speaker today, Mr. Franklin Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. A fly begins buzzing around his head. He laughs derisivel almost to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Groton, where I graduated from high school, our beloved Headmaster encouraged his students to enter public life... He looks up and catches the glazed eyes of an undernouris child which unsettles him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I chose to attend Harvard for my undergraduate work and then Columbia for my law degree.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: e takes in their uncomprehending expressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I followed my Headmaster's advice and sought a career in public life. But circumstances beyond my control have made that... very difficult...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at his tiny audience, all of whom know somethin about circumstances beyond their control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've given many speeches in my life... I don't know why I'm having such a hard time making this one... Horrified and unable to speak, Franklin seems temporarily lost, but the tiny audience doesn't seem to notice. They see Franklin. 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God did you see how they were looking at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They welcomed your company, Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't patronize me. Tom is losing his patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't patronize them. These people go to bed night after night with half-empty stomachs -- your legs are the least of their worries. They continue to drive in silence. 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a cold day and Franklin is swimming in the pool. Roy is wearing a sweater. Aunt Sally is there, too, weari patched up coat with a scarf around her neck. Tom is near raking leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roosevelt, aren't you cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roosevelt, you're gonna catch the chill if you don't get out of the water. Franklin ignores them and dips under the water as Tom com over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to tell him, Mr. Loyless. He won't listen to us. Franklin comes up from under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin, we need to talk... Normally we close up this time of year and the staff goes home for the holidays. Franklin looks at Tom, then at Roy and Aunt Sally, acknowledging. The sound of a TRAIN WHISTLE is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WHISTLE is coming from a MODEL TRAIN as it zooms arou track set up on a table in the Roosevelt living room. Ell now 15, is mesmerized. Sara sits at a piano between FRANKLIN, JR., 9, and JOHN, They are finishing a rousing rendition of "Angels We Have Heard on High" as an enormous Christmas tree gets decorat JAMES, 18, is at the top of a ladder while his sister, AN 19, decorates from the lowest rung. Eleanor holds up a tiny porcelain ornament to Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandmother Delano brought this from China. Franklin, working from his wheelchair is filling out the lower branches of the tree, his lap filled with ornaments

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to China, Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Elliot. Just your grandmama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I adored China. It smelled of ginger cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: et's go in the backyard and dig our way there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like an adventure. Anna looks over at her father, sadly and Franklin catches eye. She quickly looks away. From behind his back, John, pulls out the Christmas star places it on his father's knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it on top. Silence descends over the room. No one dares to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to James. He's the tallest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, give it to him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa always does it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do it. Franklin tosses the star in an attempt to reach the top. almost catches, but it falls to the floor. Quickly, aiding to avoid his father's embarrassment, Jame climbs back up and puts the star on top. Sara sensing the awkwardness of the moment begins to play and sing an over cheery rendition of "Hark! The Herald Angels Sing."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 Roy is spotting Franklin as he pulls himself along a set parallel bars. Eleanor observes as Franklin uses his arms drag his legs behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an extraordinary turnout this afternoon. Louis says there were over two hundred people in the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's marvelous, Babs. Eleanor is flushed with pride. Franklin, catching her loo slips slightly on the bars as Roy grabs hold of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got you, sir. Franklin then takes note that Eleanor's expression has tu to one of pure heartbreak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wonder why I want to go back to Georgia... it's to avoid people who look at me the way you just did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You truly believe the waters... (with difficulty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... that they are helping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me as if I were a child. Choosing your words so carefully...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I was! Talk to me like I was! Roy turns Franklin around on the bars and they begin walk away from Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 Franklin is being lifted out of Pete's wagon by Roy and placed into his wheelchair. He sees Tom approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sight for sore eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We missed you at the station...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smile on Franklin's face slips to a look of shock as takes in Tom's changed appearance. His face is sallow and trademark white suit is hanging on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just an ulcer. I can't eat anything I like anymore. Roy carries the luggage into the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father had ulcers. Damn irritating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they are. A silence hangs in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready to swim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 Franklin now dressed in his bathing suit is being wheeled Roy. Tom follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got some new guests. Some paying, some non-paying... As they get closer, Franklin is stunned by what he sees - A DOZEN PEOPLE -- all in different groupings -- some on crutches, others in wheelchairs, are gathered around the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in blazes?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interview you gave was syndicated in Sunday papers all over the country. Franklin looks up at Tom, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This news hits Franklin with the force of a sledgehammer. PAT DOYLE, 50, is stuffed into his wheelchair with a huge cigar between his fat lips. is eyebrows have a life of their own. He wheels himself t Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roosevelt, Pat Doyle. I've come all the way from Minneapolis to shake your hand, sir. He reaches out his hand to Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuck in this chair I do nothing but read. Newspapers, mostly. Usually I'm just looking for something -- anything -- that'll tell me there's even the slightest chance I'll walk again. Franklin is uncomfortable, especially as Pat won't let go his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're here. And we're here. Together... we'll think of something. Franklin looks to Tom and gestures for him to come closer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 Franklin is pushing the chair himself along the dirt path his anger propelling F him away from Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want no part of this. I come here for privacy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't your personal spa! I have a business to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. You have a business to run, not I! TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's asking anything of you! FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they are! TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what it took for most of them to get here? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my concern. I want to be left alone! TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, you're afraid of these people. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid? What you're talking about? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look at them with the same repulsion and pity as everyone else. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous. I resent your trying to -- TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to be around them because then that would make you one of them, wouldn't it? Franklin furiously wheels himself back towards the cottag getting stuck on the dirt path along the way. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it! Tom comes to his aid but he is brushed off by Franklin. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of my way! Get out of my goddamn way! Franklin wheels himself off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 Franklin, in his wheelchair, smokes a cigarette. His bags next to him, as is Roy. A train's whistle BLOWS and pulls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on time. Franklin sees someone else on the platform. He squints in distance. It's Tom. He walks closer towards Franklin and Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. Franklin nods in Tom's general direction. Tom has a teleg in his hand which peaks Franklin's curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expecting someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The train comes to a complete stop. A CONDUCTOR steps out onto the platform. A single ELDERLY WOMAN gets off the tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Conductor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a young gentleman by the name of Botts. Fred Botts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know anything about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect he would be in a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the cripple? He's in the baggage car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 Tom, Franklin and Roy are in front of the large door as t Conductor pushes it back slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 Amongst crates and luggage is FRED BOTTS, a young man of fifteen lying on the floor, unconscious. A wheelchair is to him, turned over on its side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother of God. Tom leaps up and into the car as does Roy leaving Frankli below. Tom takes his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His pulse is slow. 75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy lays Fred on a bench. Franklin wheels himself over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, can you hear me? Tom brings a cup of water. Franklin puts it to Fred's lip

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred? Fred opens his eyes. They are large and brown with a sweetness to them. His face comes alive when he recognize Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roosevelt?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be all right, son.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: e hands Franklin a worn newspaper clipping from his pocke The headline reads: "FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT SWIMS HIS WAY TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conductor wouldn't let me ride in the passenger car with my chair. Franklin looks at the clipping, then at Fred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you last eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knoxville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knoxville had to be three days ago. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, take him to the car. As Roy lifts Fred in his arms, Franklin wheels himself to engine car. Tom follows as they approach the CONDUCTOR. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
