dialogues.text: Who in their right mind let's a child ride in the baggage car! You could have killed that boy. CONDUCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had polio. Probably still contagious. The Conductor walks away, dismissively. Franklin pushes h chair up and stops the Conductor in his tracks. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't dismiss me because I sit in this chair! CONDUCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from me. Franklin pushes the wheels of his chair with such force h knocks the Conductor over. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ignorant son of a bitch. If I could, I'd get up right now and lock you in that box car! See how you like it! TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin... The Conductor struggles to get up. CONDUCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get this lunatic off me! Franklin wheels himself towards Tom's car where Fred is n lying across the back seat. The sight of Fred drains all anger from Franklin's face. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the nearest hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atlanta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer, but not by much. The train whistle BLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Train's ready. Franklin looks at Fred, then at Roy and Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 Fred lays in Franklin's bed while Franklin sits by the bedside. Roy lays a cold compress on Fred's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: ranklin is using his watch to take Fred's pulse. Roy pulls back the sheet to give Fred air revealing his withered legs. Alabaster skin stretched over bones. Franklin looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 77 Franklin sits at a card table with his check book in fron him. Tom stands before him, shifting uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many can pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fewer than half. Franklin opens the check book and begins writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want these people in the cottages, not in the inn. It's safer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's the way it has to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already had some complaints. (awkwardly) This is the start of the season, Franklin. I've got regulars who have come for years. Healthy folks over all... They're threatening to check out, afraid they might catch polio. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such ignorance! Don't they know that after the fever breaks we are no longer contagious? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to have to ask that you not use the pool during regular hours. I'll put time aside for you late in the day... and it won't be possible for you to eat in the dining room either. But I promise I'll find someplace suitable. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't want us to eat in their presence? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course for you I can make other accommodations. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) That won't be necessary. Franklin goes back to writing out the check. Tom stands waiting, the sound of the pen scratching seemingly interminable. Their mutual discomfort is obvious. Franklin rips the check from the ledger and holds it for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still need a doctor here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Fred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 78 Franklin is in his wheelchair, writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Babs, Things are very different upon my return." 7 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor sits in a chair reading Franklin's letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am taking on responsibilities which none of my schooling in the spheres of higher learning or politics could have prepared me for... I have seen the casualties of war. But I have never seen this, a suffering so insidious, so silent, that it rattles my soul."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 Franklin is tucking Fred in for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can I swim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon. When you're a little stronger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm asleep, in my dreams, I can still walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has it been... since you walked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine years. I'd just learned to ride a bike. After I got sick my mom was sure that the bike had caused it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she sell it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She took it out back and shot it. Franklin howls with laughter, joined by Fred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 Franklin is in the pool with the new guests. They are all nervously waiting to test the water. From the looks on their faces it's clear they only want t take their cues from Franklin. A MOTHER carries her adorable 4 year old GIRL into the wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who is this delightful child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giggling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right Daisy, try and kick your legs. Daisy wiggles back and forth in her MOTHER's arms giving her very best effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent, Daisy! JAKE PERRINI, 32, Bronx-born with an upper body of steel wheels over to Roy who is fixing a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake Perrini, Bronx, New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin'? Jake reaches out his hand to shake. Roy is unsure what to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon -- I won't bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his hand) Mighty fine, sir. Mighty fine. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, would you mind pulling me outta this trap, Roy? I wanna get airborne. Roy gently lifts Jake up and out of his chair, into his a like a child. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me one more favor? Throw me in? Roy tosses Jake to the heavens and he SAILS through the a emitting a jungle cry of pure emotional release before SPLASHING down hard in the water.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: e bobs up to the surface. There is applause. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now folks, these exercises are of my own devising so bear with me. Some laugh, some are confused. This is new territory for everyone. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hope is that in repeating these movements over and over in the water I'm in some way causing the muscles to regenerate themselves and repair the damage. He swims to the edge of the pool. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So everybody grab the edge of the pool and move what you can! hey disperse, eagerly ready to do what Franklin tells the FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead now, do your best! Their legs barely rise up to splash the surface. Undeterr Franklin leads them on, spiritedly. In the distance we see Tom, leaning against a tree, watch everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 Tom oversees the dinner service of paying guests -- none whom have disabilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 Segregated in a back room, all the polio guests are gathe for dinner seated around a couple of sawhorses with old d thrown across them serving as makeshift dining tables. Roy carries DAISY in and places her in the chair next to Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a reservation? She begins to giggle. It's infectious and soon everyone h smile on their face, overriding the awkwardness of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether in here or our there, I guarantee you the food will taste the same... terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we pray first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By all means. Would you do us the honor? Franklin bows his head for grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless the food on our table. Keep us healthy, strong and able. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Louis in tow, Eleanor is touring the exterior of an ironworks factory. She is the only woman in a large gathe of men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My dear Franklin, I too am embarking on an altogether remarkable experience." 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 leanor stands against a banner that reads "CHILD WELFARE LEAGUE." She is passing out pamphlets to a small crowd th has gathered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It seems everywhere I go there are more people in dire need of help. It would be overwhelming if not for my deep belief that help is possible..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 Eleanor is being introduced by Louis to members of the Ne York State Assembly -- all men -- eager to shake her hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Louis's latest flash of brilliance is to take me 'mainstream.' He said that you would know what he means by this."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 Franklin is in the water. Roy lifts Fred out of his wheelchair and gently puts him in the shallow end. Frankl receives him. Fred's face is ecstatic as he floats on his back in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I hope you are finding your work to be gratifying in both mind and heart. Your beloved, Eleanor."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88 A very old car comes coughing in, steam hissing from its engine. HELENA MAHONEY, 43, gets out of the driver's seat. Her ir will is matched only by her deep reserves of empathy. She gets a good look at the Inn. This is what she has come fo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 Franklin and Roy, having finished lunch, are playing checkers. Fred is sitting nearby eating a piece of pie. Helena approaches. Roy pulls off a triple jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! ROY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King me. Franklin reluctantly tops Roy's checker. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're losing, Doc. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc? I'm sorry, you're Franklin Roosevelt, aren't you? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends. (suspiciously) Are you a lawyer? HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Roosevelt it is. Wait! He jumps one of Roy's checkers. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Helena Mahoney. I'm a physical therapist. (off their blank looks) You have no idea who I am, do you? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I? HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote you a letter right after I saw the article in the paper. Didn't you read it? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It got read, I assure you. But probably not by me. Helena glances down at the checkerboard and points to it. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Roy) He's open right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sure is. Roy trounces Franklin with three swift moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am. Helena sits at the table with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been studying the effects of moist heat on polio patients and I think with repeated exercise in warm water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can help them regain lost strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredibly I've come to the same conclusion myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a half-smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're the doctor. 90

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helena is wheeling Franklin around the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ramps, no running water, no doctors... from the article in the newspaper I assumed this was a rehabilitation center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't believe everything you read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I was brought here under false pretenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join the club. (

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 Franklin lies across a makeshift examining table. Helena' examination is in progress. She is completely absorbed -- all business -- pouring ove his muscles inch by inch. She kneads, bends and stretches them with a laser-like focus, finally picking up Franklin leg and rotating it out and around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Push against my hand. Franklin, with difficulty, tries to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the good news first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your gluteus maximus is better than I hoped. It will serve you well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be all that sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. Your right leg has some movement along the thigh. That's good because we can use it to help extend your hip, flex your knee and rotate your tibia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to walk on one side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The water may help build some strength I'm not able to see yet. But to do that you would need to swim in the water much of the day. Not the limited hours you have now. a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should this place cater to a few able-bodied folk when it could be opened year round with polios?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 Tom is pushing Franklin in his wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a need for a place like this, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you aware NKLIN(cont'd) FRA that in the last

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: epidemic over 16,000 people got polio in the New York area alone? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you've been reading up. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish there was more to read. Damn few things being written about any of this. To think of someone like Fred... locked away... his mind and heart so vibrant... TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a waste. An awful waste. Franklin takes a beat -- the weight of this sinking in. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the acreage here? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roughly twelve hundred or so. Why? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to buy it. I think it would make one hell of an investment. TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Investment? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve hundred acres? Enough for two resorts, don't you think? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would take money. There's a lot of land, rebuilding the inn, adding ramps and so many people can't pay... FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undeterred) Do you think old Peabody will sell? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll sell. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you be so sure? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you taken a look at this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 Franklin sits in his chair at a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (full of charm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peabody you old reprobate! How are you? Tom is pacing back and forth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never guess why I'm calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 Helena is training a group of YOUNG MEN how to lift and c using a raven haired young woman, ELOISE HUTCHISON, 18, a the test model. She sits shyly in her wheelchair before t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woodhall, this is Eloise. Lift her gently. WOODHALL BUSEY, 17, has bright red hair and a face full o freckles. Over six feet tall he has spent his life workin the fields.          W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. He picks Eloise up effortlessly, then sets her back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good! Watch her braces. Woodhall kneels before Eloise like Prince Charming, caref straightening out her legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're light as a ... He notices the long jagged scars along Eloise's wrists. Eloise, sensing his eyes, self-consciously pulls down her sleeves. He stares at her questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a dancer... Tom and Franklin come out. Franklin gives a questioning l to Helena, pondering how these boys have suddenly appeare

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news... I raided the pool hall. I call them my Push Boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome Push Boys! Good day, Eloise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to tell them your good news? Franklin is smiling like the cat that ate the canary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hardly a done deal, but for better or worse, you may be looking at the new owner of this God- forsaken place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 A free wheeling game of poker. Heavy with cigarette and c smoke, Franklin, Tom, Fred, Jake and Pat are playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polio's always going to be a losing financial proposition, but it doesn't mean you shouldn't buy the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am buying it. Make no mistake about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind my asking, how will people pay for the services you are going to offer here? Most people with polio have a hard enough time making ends meet as it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy makes a good point, Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everything in this world has to be about profits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see your twenty-five and raise you twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon will ya! The night's still young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's twenty-five cents not twenty- five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind him, Tom. He's a cheap bastard. Fred and Pat fold immediately as does Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too rich for my blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine! Here's your twenty-five! You better have something. They eyeball each other. Gunfight at the O.K. Corral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. I was bluffing. Gleefully, Jake slaps his hands together and rakes in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing Franklin a fresh deck)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your deal, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Gentlemen, the game is Five Card Stud, sevens are wild. Everyone groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sevens are wild and you can all go to Hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 The sun is about to rise. Tom's car is parked in front of Inn, pulled up very close to the main entrance. The trunk open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, struggling with a suitcase, comes down the ramp. He deposits it in the trunk and then walks precariously back the ramp, having difficulty navigating the incline. He goes back into the house for one last bag. When he com out, he's surprised by what he sees -- FRANKLIN (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going? Franklin is being pushed by Roy in his wheelchair. They a both dressed in pajamas and bathrobes, though Franklin ha blanket around his shoulders to shield him from the morni chill. Tom is caught. This is everything he wanted to avoid. TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going to Asheville to see my parents. From the sight of Tom's car stuffed with luggage, it is c he is not coming back. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do this without you... we're only just beginning. TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. (You're beginning, not me. a beat) I've got cancer, Franklin. It's spread everywhere. Franklin is stunned -- utterly thrown. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I'll take you to the best doctors. We'll go to Atlanta right now -- TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen the best doctors. When you were in New York they opened me up for the second time. Now I just want to die in the bed I was born. Franklin is struggling with this. TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to do great things. This place has an identity now -- a purpose. It has you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any guard Franklin had is gone. He reaches out and takes by the sleeve slipping his hand into Tom's gripping it ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God be with you, Mr. Loyless. Tom takes one last look at Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never pitied me. Thank you for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary, I envy you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will miss you all the days of my life. Tom gets into his car and looks at Franklin with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Franklin. With a wave he slowly lurches down the long driveway and turns onto the main road. Franklin watches the car until is out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 Sara paces wildly, waving a letter at Eleanor and Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to use his entire trust fund to buy that... leper colony!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin has invited Louis and me to see the work he's been doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (derisively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work! Playing in a pool all day long? Squandering his birthright on a group of fawning strangers? I consider this your fault, Eleanor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have indulged him and this is the result.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (challenging her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indulged him? I have indulged him? Sara looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a grown man who makes his own decisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he does not need to buy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's of any comfort to you, I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm against it as well. It will consume too much of his time and energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it is settled. We tell him no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it is not settled. We must hear him out. Louis and I must see for ourselves the work that he has been doing then we will all discuss this further. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: nd tell him no. They all look at each other for a moment. For once they a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I have underestimated you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you have. But that has been my fault, not yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 Fred, on crutches, swings himself up using one side and t the next under Helena's supervision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent, Fred! Keep going... They are surrounded by many others, Franklin, Eloise, Woodhall, Pat and Jake. The BEEPING of a car horn gets their immediate attention. Roy leaps off the porch, skipping the stairs as his broth Pete drives up in Tom's car. He parks it and steps out. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Mr. Roosevelt. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, what are you doing with Tom's car? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was as sorry as anyone to hear about Mr. Loyless's passing. Wished he coulda' lived to see this! FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Loyless had me come up and fetch this right after he brung it to Asheville. "Pete, he said, "Take this home and fix it up for Mr. Roosevelt." FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete... I can't drive a car. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can now. Roy opens the passenger door and lifts Franklin into the driver's seat. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on in and I'll teach ya'! He begins showing off a system of pulleys and levers that have been attached to both pedals. They thread through ho in a second dashboard, attached to polished wood knobs. It's a hand-controlled automobile. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one there is your brake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this here's the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot damn! You got hand controls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a thing of beauty! Franklin begins running his hands over the polished wood

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you got to push it real smooth or it goes all herky-jerky. Franklin excitedly turns the key and starts it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, Mr. Roosevelt, you're not ready to drive yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes I am! Franklin hits the gas as the car begins HALTING and JERKI the whole way down the driveway. Pete is yelling out instructions but Franklin ignores him. They all watch as he pulls away. As the car hits the end of the driveway Franklin reaches across Pete and opens his passenger door pushing him out. Franklin tears off alone -- out on his first solo spin.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: ranklin is driving by himself with the top down, thrilled be moving on his own. No one is pushing him. He's free. T car covers miles of farmland, passing pine forests, peach orchards and cotton fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 A spent and anxious Eleanor, with Louis in tow, stands on station platform, suitcase in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a far cry from Grand Central Station. They are both silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wire said someone would be here to pick us up. The sounds of tires screeching and a car horn cause them turn around. It is Franklin, sitting in the driver's seat of his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your chariot awaits, Madame! Louis promptly drops the luggage. Then he and Eleanor wal over to the car, taking in the hand-controls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you learn to drive this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday! 101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin drives wild and fast. Louis hat flies right off head. Eleanor just holds on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 Franklin, Eleanor and Louis pull up to the Inn. Though th brush has been cleared and the trees are newly trimmed, i still a wreck. Franklin is too proud to concede Louis and Eleanor's disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't wait to give you the tour!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 Franklin wheels himself along the circular driveway, poin things out, almost manic in his energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small schoolhouse will go there. We need it badly as many of the children are barred from the local schools due to their infirmities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a dilapidated gardener's shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We also require a blacksmith's shop so we can craft braces here on the premises. I've found a wonderful local man who can make crutches and canes. His work is outstanding. Of course what is most desperately needed is a hospital. That's going to put my fund raising abilities to the test. Franklin wheels himself up a ramp to the Inn as Eleanor a Louis follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104 Surrounded by peeling wallpaper and threadbare furniture

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor and Louis exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly are you proposing, Franklin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That this will be the first polio rehabilitation and treatment center in the world. My personal trust almost covers the price of the Inn and the surrounding land. There will be a modest tuition charged to the patients which should hold us over while I seek out investors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin, you're risking everything you have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there are other costs to consider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama will see that the children are provided for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not speaking of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have found something here which makes waking up in the morning remotely bearable and the two of you stand there... ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin, I need for you to be practical and realistic. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) Practical? I am trapped inside a body that no longer moves of my own volition. I am trying to be practical. Now either you're with me or against me. In or out! ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care for ultimatums disguised as debate. Eleanor starts to leave. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Eleanor! Get back here. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will see you gentlemen tonight. She leaves. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't talk to her like that. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really? Are you an expert on this now? How should I speak to my wife, Louis? LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the respect she deserves. (a beat) Look, I don't deny the work you're doing here could be important -- FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The issue is whether you want to run a rehabilitation center or whether you want to run for office again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I can walk, I'll run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 Eleanor approaches the pool. It is as quiet as a church. is stunned to observe over a dozen tables set up in the water. On each table is a child or an adult polio wearing their bathing suit. Next to them is a Physical Therapist also i bathing attire conducting therapy. In hushed tones the Physical Therapists encourage and work the distressed lim of the patients as Helena swims to each table overseeing work being done. Eleanor sits down in a chair and watches fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 106 The camera pans various tables revealing legs in braces, legs in wheelchairs, shapely legs, flaccid legs, children legs... some reveal illicit romances, betrayed by secret hand holding and hands on thighs. Jake and a new physical therapist, MARY BETH, are particularly cozy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a very special night we're celebrating. At last we are together eating in this dining room! The hands come up and out from under the table, applaudin

dialogues.speaker: ON FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: He is in his wheelchair dressed in a jacket and tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now please join me in welcoming Miss Jackie Mills, a new arrival along with her father, Samuel, all the way from Oakland, California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight years old with black hair. Her legs are in braces a she grips her father's hand tightly.

dialogues.speaker: ON FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us also take this opportunity to welcome our two able-bodied guests, Mr. Louis Howe and my better half, Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: ON ELEANOR AND LOUIS
dialogues.text: Waving politely from their seats. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now for the musical portion of our program... JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! I can't let this opportunity pass without saying out loud what a lot of us feel in our hearts right now. (a beat) You're a man among men, Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And women! DAISY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And children! JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) It's a real democracy at Warm Springs -- everybody gets heard! (to Franklin) You listening? Eleanor, seated next to Franklin, watches as Franklin, in rare moment of emotional nakedness, is at a loss for word JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then, if I may do the honors of presenting to you the lovely Miss Eloise Hutchison of Cottage C. Eloise wheels herself out. In a sweet, but untrained voic she begins the introduction to her song:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELOISE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) "Think of what you're losing by constantly refusing to dance with me.

dialogues.speaker: Y
dialogues.text: Aou'd be the idol of France with me. nd yet you stand there And shake your foolish head dramatically,

dialogues.speaker: W
dialogues.text: hile I sit here so ecstatically. You just look and say emphatically: Not this season! There's a reason!" Some members of the audience begin to smile, knowing what coming. Various STAFF step out from the kitchen to watch. Eloise is joined by three others -- all of them in wheelc ELOISE & CHORUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) "I won't dance! Don't ask me! I won't dance! Don't ask me; I won't dance, monsieur, with you." Simple, but clever choreography utilizing the wheelchairs has the audience cheering. ELOISE & CHORUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My heart won't let my feet do C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: things they should do." HORUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You know what? You're lovely." ELOISE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And so what? I'm lovely." CHORUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "But oh! What you do to me! I'm like an ocean wave that's bumped on the shore; I feel so absolutely stumped on the floor!" This is too much for the crowd, including Franklin, Elean and Louis. They laugh and cry in equal measure at the sig of Eloise and her Chorus. The song finished, Franklin quiets down the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we say good night, I understand our Royal-Taskmaster- in-Residence, Miss Mahoney, insists on having the last word. Helena rises from her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think words describe adequately what Daisy and I would like to show all of you. (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready, Daisy? Daisy's mother, Cecile, carries Daisy to the center of th room where Helena meets them. Helena bends down and remov Daisy's braces. The room is hushed. Daisy then begins to WALK tentatively towards her mother.

dialogues.speaker: ON FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Overwhelmed by what is taking place. He looks around and takes in the sight of so many different faces... Some are beaming, some are fighting back tears, some look away... the sight of it almost too painful... a reminder their own private battles.

dialogues.speaker: ON DAISY
dialogues.text: Only a step or two away from her mother she FALLS the sho distance and lands in her mother's outstretched arms. WILD CHEERS go up in the room while Daisy's face glows wi pride. She connects with Franklin, who matches her smile his own -- genuine and beatific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 Roy lifts Franklin out of the wheelchair and on to the be Eleanor enters holding a lit candle. Roy is about to begin Franklin's bedtime routine, but Ele gently reaches out and touches him on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy looks to Franklin, who nods it's all right, and exits Eleanor closes the door and puts the candle on the bureau

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: fter a beat, Franklin begins to unbuckle his pants. He th lies back on the bed. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your most pressing concern? Eleanor kneels before him and tugs the pants down, slowly as not to catch on the braces. Eleanor folds the pants and carefully places them over th back of a chair. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting a doctor to live on the premises full-time. Someone who, at the very least, could monitor our progress. Make us legitimate. She begins to take off Franklin's braces -- a series of intricate buckles. Eleanor slides the braces off his legs. His legs, though deeply tanned are withered and spindly. He is still weari his shoes. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that costs more money. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Eleanor puts the heavy braces against the wall and kneels once again to untie his shoelaces. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the real problem is no one is interested. The annual Orthopedics Convention is being held in Atlanta this weekend and I offered to speak. (his anger surfacing) They turned me down flat. Eleanor takes Franklin's pajama bottoms off the bed and w tender care pulls them up his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few weeks ago, the conditions at a garment factory on West 27th Street were brought to my attention. The owners claimed everything was satisfactory, but would never let anyone in to conduct a proper inspection. She reaches for Franklin's hands and pulls him up to a se position. They are now face to face. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It took awhile, but we finally got in. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We? He searches her face for clues as to the woman she's beco He starts to unbutton his shirt and put on his pajama top Eleanor sits in a chair across from him. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I showed up with someone from the Labor Board and we refused to leave until they let us in. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you suggesting? ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the risk of my good standing with the Junior Assistance League, I suggest we crash the party. She stands and walks over to Franklin and runs her hand through his hair.    E LEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Franklin. She goes to the door and opens it letting in a shaft of l against the candle-lit room. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Babs. She blows the candle out and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108 Franklin's car pulls up to a massive stone building built Greek revival style. Franklin looks intimidated -- there two dozen stairs leading up to the main entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 Roy climbs the stairs like a stevedore with Franklin slun over his shoulder. Using enormous force, Eleanor is pulli the chair up and over each step while walking backwards u the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 The stage is lit with a skeleton hanging on a stand and l projections on a screen of spinal discs while a DOCTOR, i dull litany, intones a prepared speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clinical situation where the radicular or nerve root is compressed by the prolapsed disc is referred to as a radiculopathy. Double doors fly open with a BANG as all heads turn to se Franklin and Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sorry we're late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon! Eleanor talks quickly while wheeling Franklin down the ai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (introducing herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor Roosevelt, niece of the late President Theodore Roosevelt and this is my husband, Franklin, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto to Eleanor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure this worked on 27th Street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seemed to at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the befuddled Doctor on stage whose name tag reads, "Dr. Bissell." ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dr. Bissell for agreeing to let us share the stage with you today. It was so generous of you. Dr. Bissell smiles limply, saving face. The audience vagu applauds. Franklin and Eleanor are now center stage. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband, as many of you may have read, is a victim of polio. However, victim is only a definition, not a state of mind. Franklin? He looks at her completely amazed. Eleanor gives him an F

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: encouraging nod to take over. RANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all know that poor circulation is a chronic problem for limbs damaged by polio... I've never been able to swim more than a few minutes without becoming too cold. But there's a place, gentlemen... a miraculous place not three hours from here where the water is filled with natural minerals at a temperature of almost 90 degrees. That place, gentlemen, is called Warm Springs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One DOCTOR in particular, 60's, leans forward in his chai listening with great interest. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patients can stay in these waters for up to an hour. This is essential in allowing them the time to work on strengthening their muscles. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have come to the shared conclusion that research for the cause and the cure for infantile paralysis is paramount. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, until NOR(cont'd) ELEA that day arrives

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: more emphasis has be placed on rehabilitation. We personally invite you to Warm Springs to come and take a look. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: These "men of science" are mesmerized by Eleanor's style, both warm and immediate. She has disarmed them with her l of pretension. ON FRANKLIN and ELEANOR Their two separate journeys intersecting -- lightning in bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 111 There is a receiving line in place to get a last word or autograph with Franklin and Eleanor. DR. WILLIS, bespectacled, speaks with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you speak at the Legion Hall in Cleveland last Spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the League of Women Voters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You created quite a stir. Not sure you'll be asked back. Franklin is ready to intervene but Eleanor puts her hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his shoulder stopping him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I believe you must say what you feel in your heart -- what you feel is right, for you'll be criticized anyway. Damned if you do -- damned if you don't. DR. HEBERT, military in bearing -- the doctor who listene intensely -- steps up in line and shakes hands with Elean and then Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Peter Hebert. I've been doing my own studies in this area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. HEBERT(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is possible I'd like to come and make an evaluation for the Journal of Orthopedic Medicine. Franklin looks to Eleanor, elated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sooner the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112 Roy is fast asleep tucked around the wheelchair in the ba seat. Franklin smiles in Eleanor's direction. She looks back at shyly and smiles in return. But her expression changes wh she sees something in his eyes -- something she hasn't se for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? Franklin reaches out and takes her hand, pulling her clos He stretches his whole arm around her and places her hand one of the driving knobs, his hand on top of hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll teach you. They operate the car together -- their connection complet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 Franklin and Eleanor are sitting in the front seat of the car. Louis is already up on the train platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll break the news to Mama. Franklin smiles as they look at each other like two naugh children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's going to be fun. Eleanor bursts out laughing, Franklin joins in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babs... words fail me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You? Franklin Roosevelt? She leans in and kisses Franklin on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do so love you. She slides out of the car and goes up to the platform and

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: boards the train while Franklin watches her. Farmer and his Wife from the school house graduation approach Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roosevelt you lookin' mighty fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine day, isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. How's the Boll Weevil situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect the Boll Weevil is always gonna be a situation, Mr. Roosevelt, but thanks for askin'. Franklin's energy and vitality are infectious. The politi within him is being reborn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 114 A beaming Eleanor sits down next to Louis. He too is look very pleased. Eleanor takes notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I get the feeling we're not smiling about the same thing? The train begins pulling out. They both look out at Franklin. Locals are coming up to h car surrounding him -- he is a magnet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 115 Louis is seated in the front row of the balcony of the St Assembly, his feet up on the railing, eating pistachio nu Also seated are two politicos, JAMES HASTINGS and STEPHEN TELLER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't kiss babies from a wheelchair. It'll scare their mothers half to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al Smith's got a lock on the presidential nomination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct me if I'm wrong, but don't you think even after all these years that old Al's still a little rough around the edges? They laugh knowing this is a huge understatement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin can help soften his image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him put Smith's name in nomination. Teller and Hastings are none to sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he is a helluva speech maker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but is your man up to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in the bag, guys. Count on it. Bluffing is one of Louis's strong suits and it looks like they're buying it. Just then, Louis notices a familiar face down on the floo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Stansbury, give my best to the Misses! (to Hastings and Teller)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lost weight. Must've been the prison food. 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 A line stretches outside with patients waiting to be seen Among them is Franklin, chatting with everyone else, expecting and receiving no priority attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 117 Dr. Hebert is examining Daisy. Helena is by his side, fil him in on her case history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 Helena, dressed in a robe, walks the halls of the Inn. Something is amiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 An empty wheelchair, illuminated by a sliver of moonlight On a blanket nearby are Jake and Mary Beth. he unbuttons his shirt and runs her hands over his impressively developed upper body. They begin to kiss hungrily, passionately -- completely in their own world. Several yards away, across the lawn, Eloise is in Woodhall's arms -- they are dancing. He is singing softly into her ear as they sway, her feet never touching the gr

dialogues.speaker: NT. MERIWETHER INN
dialogues.text: Helena, in a nightgown, is looking out a window into the distance. Fiercely protective and slightly envious of her charges, she pulls a pack of cigarettes from her bathrobe pocket and steals a solitary smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 Franklin seated alone on the porch in the darkness. He dr on his cigarette and the red glow illuminates the contour his face in repose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 121 Franklin is on the phone. Roy stands by his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Souders. How are you?... Couldn't be better. I was wondering if you'd found a buyer for my naval prints? (clearly not)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Well, they're in marvelous condition... All right, Souders. Oh one more thing... I have some beautiful pieces of my Grandfather's -- T'ang Dynasty... Really?... An auction in the Fall? That sounds promising. I'll be in touch. Franklin hangs up and sits deep in thought. He rubs his perspiring forehead with the back of his hand. He looks d at his hand and sees that it is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 Franklin is walking on crutches aided by Roy. Nearby, a g of children practice on parallel bars with Helena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to tell these people if I have to close things down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you did the best you could. Franklin gives Roy a look of gratitude, then notices Lion approaching with his mail bag. Lionel hands Franklin a fistful of open envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any good news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creditors are gettin' cranky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The operative word was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yah, almost forgot. The doctor that came and studied ya'll sent his report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel offers up the envelope, but then pulls it back bef handing it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save me the stamps? Franklin nods then grabs it from Lionel. He rips it open begins devouring the report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... therefore, in conclusion, my research has shown that the overwhelming majority of patients here have shown some improvement. Enough for me to recommend warm water therapy as the standard post polio treatment to the Orthopedics Society of America!" ( he grips Roy's arm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy! Something catches Franklin's eye and his smile begins to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123 Helena entering the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not as bad as you think. Franklin slams the door behind her and wheels over to the table. He throws back a drink -- clearly not his first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read it. Out loud. Page twenty-nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Of the twenty three patients examined only one, a forty-four year old male, showed little visible signs of improvement..." This is one doctor's opinion, Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep reading. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There is marked falling away of the muscle masses on either side of the spine in the lower lumbar region. His lower extremities present a most depressing picture." She brings the pages down, but Franklin gestures her to continue. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I feel after studying him that the psychological factor in his management is paramount. He has such courage and ambition. Yet at the same time he is such an extraordinarily sensitive emotional mechanism... It is difficult for her to continue. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... that it will take all the skill which we can muster to lead him successfully to a recognition of his severe physical limitations without crushing him." FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patronizing son-of-a-bitch! I wanted to walk again. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you still might. This report legitimizes we've worked so hard for. We can raise funs now. It could change everything! FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't change anything for me. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin, I won't play this game. I won't feel sorry for you. e reaches for the bottle, but Helena grabs on to it, stopping him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met a boy today, ten years old. He's paralyzed from the waist down. Why don't you go regale him with vivid tales about your trips to Europe and playing football at school. Tell him how you courted your wife and fathered children. Tell him of a life he can only dream of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a beat) I can't help you out of a hole if I climb in with you. Then we're both stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, wearing a bow tie and an oversized jacket, is proud polishing off a desktop sign that reads: "FRED BOTTS:

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR OF ADMISSIONS."
dialogues.text: Helena is behind him reading a file. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering) Here's another one he's refusin'. He throws a telegram onto an already large stack. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you read it? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't like telegrams. All them STOPS and stuff. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make you dizzy, Lionel. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little bit. Fred eyes the telegram, then impulsively grabs it, rippin open. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Would be honored if you place my name in nomination for President. STOP. The party needs you. STOP. Yours sincerely, Al Smith." LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he? (

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Governor of New York. handing it to Lionel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you slide it under his door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Probably slide it right back. Lionel leaves. Fred and Helena are silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't go. He doesn't want to be seen walking on crutches or being wheeled to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The millions listening on radio won't be able to see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all the people at the convention will. Helena nods, "That's right."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 125 Responding to a knock at the door, Roy gets up from sitti on the couch with Franklin, sullen and inattentive.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: e opens the door to Louis who walks right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Howe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Roy. Roy takes his hat and coat and exits to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you've made me come all the way back to this hell hole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to take you to Houston. You started your speech yet? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going. He stares at Franklin, drinking. Shaking his head, he goe over to the sidebar and pours one for himself. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what this is, don't you? It's a golden opportunity. A springboard for you to run for Governor. ranklin is silent. Frustrated, Louis takes a seat in Franklin's empty wheelchair. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever hear of a Civil War General named Francis Nicholls? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I never heard of him either. But this was one brave son-of-a- bitch. Fought for the Confederacy and lost his left arm in one battle and his left foot in another. Then after the war he ran and won the Governorship of Louisiana -- twice! FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a war hero. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with emphasis) Twice. (a beat) Look, I've worked like a dog to keep your name in play, grovelling at the feet of the powers-that-be in back rooms. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As much for you as for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be damned if I'm going to let you pass up a chance like this. It's time -- and you're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 126 Waiting on the porch are Eleanor and Helena, who are seat talking. Louis exits the cottage, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn. Eleanor rises and goes into the cottage as Louis takes he seat next to Helena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, so good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good to see you, Mrs. Roosevelt. She approaches a surprised Franklin. Leaning in, she runs hand across his stubbly beard. He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The report. I'll never... She sits by his side and Franklin begins to cry. His sobs grow louder connecting to the despair deep inside him. It unleashes an avalanche of grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my darling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm useless, Eleanor. I feel so useless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true. No one can make you feel inferior without your consent. Finally, his sobs subside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have done a brilliant thing here -- a magnificent thing. Eleanor picks up the E doctor's report and puts it in the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get you in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 Franklin is wheeled down to the pool by Roy and Eleanor. they get closer, Franklin makes out someone already swimm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Pop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squinting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that? ELLIOT ROOSEVELT is now 17 years old. He has his mother's enormous blue eyes and his father's natural charisma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! You getting in? Louis and Helena approach the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sense a conspiracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't seen nothin' yet. ranklin smiles, warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 129 Elliot is climbing a rope dangling high from a tree as Franklin and Eleanor look up at him. Franklin is standing crutches. Elliot descends with a flourish as Helena approaches Fran with a single cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin, let go of your crutches. You're not going to need them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to make your arms function as your legs. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that possible? HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot, go to your father and stand on his left side. ELLIOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think this may work, Pop. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor, take the crutch. Eleanor takes one crutch as Helena takes the other, repla it in Franklin's hand with a cane. Then, with Elliot on Franklin's left side she bends Ellio arm at a right angle, like a parallel bar, and hooks Franklin's left arm around his. Going over to Franklin's right side she puts a cane in hi HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Franklin) Now use your right shoulder and pull your left leg forward. He does so. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! Now with the muscles in your left shoulder, pull your right leg. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One small bump and I'll land right on my keister! HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Elliot is for. He's going to hold you up. Hitch your leg! Come on! Franklin and Elliot attempt to walk. It requires immense strength and effort on both their parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ever the taskmaster) Elliot, don't lean in -- stand up straight. Pull against him. He needs you! After one or two steps the enormity of it overwhelms Fran FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. ELLIOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm strong, pop. You can't hurt me. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can do this, Franklin! Keep going! They start the walk again. It's awkward... difficult... b it's working. LOUIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) I'll be damned. Franklin stops, exhausted. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin, are you all right? FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I'm just... Roy runs in with a chair and helps Franklin into it as Helena, Eleanor, Louis, Elliot and Roy all look at him, concerned. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a replacement for the real work we're doing to get you on your feet again, understand? No one is throwing in the towel or even agreeing with that doctor's report... FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. HELENA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's not practical --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's political. Franklin looks at Louis, then to Eleanor, and realizes th this could be it. 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 Franklin and Elliot are walking. Helena is close behind, coaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use Elliot, not the cane. Switch your weight to Elliot... good! Keep your head up. Off to the side Pat, Jake, Eloise, Woodhall and Daisy are having an informal picnic, observing Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is he working so hard to hide it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I disagree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you disagree? "There but for the grace of God goes us," that's what they're saying. As if our bodies is who we are, but it's not. It's our souls is who we are, but they don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish he could just wheel himself out there in front of everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't do that Eloise, it's politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not gonna matter if he hides his legs as long as he don't hide what he knows. And what he knows is what it's like to be one of us. ranklin, getting closer, raises his cane in greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, everyone! Off-balance Franklin goes down hard bringing Elliot down him. Eleanor, Louis and Roy all rush to his aid, but Helena is there first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a moment to catch your breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. You okay son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fell down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did, Daisy. Twelfth time today. Must be a new record! Daisy laughs as do the others, though some can't hide the concern. Franklin struggles hard as Roy and Elliot help him to his feet. 131

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor is packing Franklin's suitcase while Franklin, sitting up in bed dressed in pajamas, works on his speech

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading aloud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so America must find... ( reconsidering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, America needs a pathfinder... Louis, pacing in shirtsleeves, nods approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To emblaze the trail along a high road that will avoid... avoid the bottomless morass... Discouraged, Franklin pushes aside the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I fall... trying to get to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you fall, you show them how to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, if I fall in front of thousands of people I lose everything but their pity. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be writing my obituary before I get up off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot won't let you fall, he'll be there. All the arrangements have been made, boss. It'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are we fooling? This will never work. They'll never let me back into politics. They'll never see past my legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My darling, they'll never see past your legs unless you do. 132

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin is settling into the driver's seat of his car, a by Roy. Eleanor is seated next to him; Louis and Elliot i back. Franklin's attention is diverted by something he sees straight ahead. It is the entire Warm Springs group coming down the drive in chairs and on crutches. All the patients, the Push Boys, the physical therapists, Helena, Jake, Fred, Aunt Sally, Eloise and Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Doc -- we're not coming with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you'll be with me. No question of that. (a beat) I am proud more than you will ever know to be part of this community. (his voice growing stronger) A community based not on birthright or privilege, but on compassion and courage. The true power of these waters is that they brought us all together. Our ability to help one another is what will make our victory over polio endure. Our ability to survive... despite the odds.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: ranklin looks out at the sea of faces. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we have done and will continue to do until this disease is defeated is come together -- like a family -- and do what we do best... (his voice breaking) Lift each other up. Franklin starts the car as the crowd begins to disperse. Then, spying Helena, Franklin calls out to her. FRANKLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mahoney I need to speak with you, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Doc. Off her smile, Franklin reaches into his pocket and withd a small box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He hands it to Helena. She just stares at it, at a loss f words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it. She does so, tentatively, revealing a ladies watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't wear it in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try not to. Good luck, Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm throwing myself to the wolves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've faced worse. And if they bite, you can come back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll always come back here. Helena steps away and Franklin pulls out and down the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and deserted Roy is carrying Franklin down a flight stairs. Louis is hastily checking over his shoulder. If possible, Eleanor appears even more nervous than Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're being superstitious, Louis. There aren't any reporters here. Suddenly out of the darkness a FLASHBULB POPS revealing a dozen or more REPORTERS staring incomprehensibly at the s of a six foot, 200 lb. man being carried like a baby in t arms of a black man. No one does or says a thing. The PHOTOGRAPHER who had the wherewithal to snap the one picture raises his camera to another. But DAN REED, a reporter for The New York Herald Tribune a gentle giant at over six foot-four, reaches out and pla a massive hand over the lens. Slowly, but firmly, he pulls the camera down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ( quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis and Eleanor stand stock still, tense, watching the scene unfold Roy is sweating; his arms growing weak. Elliot brings the chair around and Roy gently lowers Franklin into it. It's a measure of Reed's standing with this group that hi authority is unquestioned. But the Photographer raises his camera again. Only now Re isn't as kind. He grabs the camera from him and opens the back, pulling out the film and exposing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tipping his hat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Mr. Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 134 The enormous arena is empty but for some maintenance WORK and JANITORS. Louis enters and makes his way to the stage He approaches dead center and stands behind the podium lo out. GRIPPING the podium hard he ROCKS it back and forth. Taking no chances, he pulls a hammer out from the rear of waistband and a bunch of nails from his coat pocket. Looking around to see if anyone is paying any attention t him he quickly ducks down behind the podium. The sound of HAMMERING fills the hall as Louis, on his kn NAILS the podium to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 135 Twenty thousand CONVENTIONEERS are roasting in the hall. is Houston in the summer and it's broiling hot. A sea of held red, white and blue fans are being waved all at once most bearing the words "SMITH FOR PRESIDENT." Near the stage is a long table where the new breed of RAD REPORTERS are seated, each in front of a primitive lookin microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hovering in a group off to the side are Dan Reed and the REPORTERS from the previous night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 136 Franklin is standing ramrod straight holding onto Elliot' arm. He looks handsome in a navy pin-striped suit. As everyone else is sweating no one notices that Franklin is perspiring more than F most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she seated? Louis, a human train wreck himself, reaches over to mop Franklin's brow with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a box stage left. Give me your hand. Franklin takes his hand off his cane. It's soaking wet. L wipes it, gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, what the hell am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Putting your big toe in the water. Just then, a VOICE booms out from the loudspeakers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to introduce to you a man who as Assistant Secretary of the Navy served our country with distinction. member of an illustrious family

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of long-standing political commitment to our great nation... Ladies and gentlemen: Franklin Delano Roosevelt! Franklin turns to Elliot and they both take deep breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Elliot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. The curtains part and they begin moving forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 A BLINDING SPOTLIGHT picks up Franklin and Elliot. The SPOTLIGHT follows them as they make their way to the podi Franklin is hitching each leg forward, slowly. The tip of cane hits the floor with pinpoint accuracy for balance an support. He leans heavily on Elliot's arm. The walk appears effort He chats with Elliot the whole way, still managing to fla the CONVENTIONEERS his million dollar smile. But the walk slow and the ovation is beginning to fade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ouis stands in the wings clutching the curtain with one h and covering his eyes with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 139 Eleanor sits looking down at her lap, afraid to even brea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 140 Franklin and Elliot are still ten steps away from the pod Sensing the crowd noise weakening, he whispers to Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laugh as if I'm making a joke. Elliot throws back his head and laughs. The crowd, wantin be in on it, rise as one in a sustained CHEER! But a puddle of sweat caused by the dripping perspiration from Franklin's hands is causing the tip of his cane to s Elliot, ever aware, grips him tighter, averting disaster finally they reach the podium. Franklin grabs one side of the podium while Elliot, with sleight of hand Houdini would admire, LOCKS his father's braces, whisks the cane away, pulls his father's speech f his breast pocket and lays it smoothly on the podium. THE VIEW FROM BEHIND displays how Franklin's legs are spr wide for stability as he clutches the podium. He holds on tightly, as if the wood might snap from his grip. FROM OUT FRONT the crowd sees only a powerful man standin tall amidst the flashbulbs POPPING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin has made it. He is home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 141 All the denizens of Warm Springs are crowded around the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here on the stage is Franklin Roosevelt... a figure tall and proud even in suffering; a face of classic profile; a frame nervous and yet self-controlled. A man softened, cleansed and illumined with pain. 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOVERNOR AL SMITH, 51, is seated by a radio, surrounded b CRONIES. An overblown Irishman with gold capped teeth and heavy New York accent. He chomps on a lit cigar that neve leaves the side of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of an ovation, Al. Couldn't have asked for anything more. Smith sits silently puffing on his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may have to be careful though. Looks like you're raising up a rival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark my words. He'll be dead in a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 143 Eleanor applauds Franklin as a REPORTER leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Roosevelt, one last question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think polio has affected your husband's mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. I certainly do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 144 Franklin stands before the crowd. His magnetism is incontestable. He radiates infinite possibility. He looks up to Eleanor's box and they smile at one anothe the crowd continues to applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 145 The mineral springs gently ripple as Franklin appears in water. As the following words appear on the screen, Frank slowly and confidently swims out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years later, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was elected President of the United States. He was elected three more times -- unprecedented in U.S. History. During his years as President, he saw the country through Great Depression and a world war waged on six continents. On April 12, 1945, in the thirteenth year of his presiden at the age of sixty-three, Franklin Roosevelt died in his cottage at Warm Springs. The beneficiary of his $562,000 life insurance policy was Warm Springs... which continues to flourish as a rehabilitation center to this day.
